title: Interpreting R-Squared Value in Gas Mileage and Speed Comparison
question_text:
The speed (in kilometers per hour) and mileage (in kilometers per liter) of $13\text{ cars}$ was measured. The regression equation is as follows:
$\text{Kilometers per liter} = -1.80 + 0.54\text{ kilometers per hour}$
$S = 7.15740$ $R^2= 64.8\%$ $R^2 \text{ (adj)} = 61.5\%$
What is a valid interpretation of $R^2$ in the context of the problem?
tables:
PredictorCoefSE CoefTP
Constant-1.88.357-0.220.833
Kilometers per hour0.53600.11924.50.001

choices.text: About $65\%$ of the observations are within one standard deviation of the mean.
About $65\%$ of the observations will follow this linear model.
About $65\%$ of the data can be explained in this situation.
About 65% of the variation in fuel economy (as measured by kilometers per liter) can be explained by the least squares regression line on speed (as measured by kilometers per hour).
About 65% of the time, the true population slope will be caught within the given interval.
